__data__.text: French governments have attempted pension reforms in recent decades to address budget deficits, focusing on a largely pay-as-you-go structure where workers and employers pay mandatory taxes to finance current retirees' pensions. Despite France's low retirement age and high pension spending (around 14% of GDP), the core pay-as-you-go system remains stable and will stay in place, providing a state-backed pension for retirees.

The French pension system, which guarantees retirement benefits and has a low poverty rate among retirees, will not undergo significant changes. Despite its stability, demographic shifts, such as increased life expectancy, have created challenges, with fewer workers supporting each retiree. Nevertheless, the state-backed pension system will persist, offering a reliable income source for retirees.

The text discusses how the ratio of workers to retirees in the French pension system has been decreasing over the years, from 2.1 in 2000 to a projected 1.2 in 2070. This trend, caused by increased life expectancy, has led to a higher cost of pensions, which has partially contributed to France's national debt rising to one of the highest levels in the EU, surpassing that of the UK and Germany. However, despite these challenges, the state-backed pension system is expected to remain stable and continue providing a reliable income source for retirees.

In a 2023 interview, Macron noted the significant increase in French pensioners, from 10 million to 17 million, due to longer lifespans. To maintain the pension system's financial viability without increasing taxpayer contributions, he proposed incrementally raising the retirement age to 64 by 2030.

In the 2023 interview, Macron introduced further pension reforms, extending the required years for workers to contribute to the system to qualify for a full pension and eliminating favorable pension rules for certain sectors, such as energy and transportation. These changes, along with the planned increase in the retirement age to 64 or 65 by 2030, aimed to preserve the pension system's financial stability without putting a heavier burden on taxpayers.

The pay-as-you-go pension system, which Macron's reforms aim to sustain, is projected to have a surplus of €3.2bn in 2022. However, the French government's pensions advisory board (COR) warns of structural deficits in the future due to increasing life expectancy and delayed entry into the workforce. By 2027, Labor Minister Olivier Dussopt estimates that the pension deficit could surpass $13bn annually if no immediate action is taken.

The French government's proposed pension reforms aim to address future structural deficits in the pay-as-you-go system, which is expected to have a surplus of €3.2bn in 2022. The government asserts that the reforms will eliminate the deficit by 2030, creating a surplus to fund early retirement for those in physically demanding jobs. The reforms, which have been contemplated by Macron's administration since his 2017 election, were initially met with protests and strikes in late 2019, leading to their postponement due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The deficit is projected to reach over $13bn annually by 2027 if no action is taken, as indicated by the French government's pensions advisory board (COR) due to increasing life expectancy and delayed workforce entry.

The French government's proposed pension reforms, initially intended to unify the pension system and eliminate future deficits, did not include raising the retirement age. However, in 2022, President Macron announced a new plan to increase the retirement age to 65 by 2031, in three-month increments per year, starting from September 2023. This change addresses the projected deficit of over $13 billion annually by 2027, caused by increased life expectancy and delayed workforce entry, as indicated by the French government's pensions advisory board (COR). The initial reforms, which aimed to remove 42 special regimes for various sectors, were postponed due to protests, strikes, and the COVID-19 pandemic.

In 2022, President Macron introduced a new pension reform plan, raising the retirement age to 65 by 2031 and increasing the required contribution period to 43 years by 2027. This adjustment is a response to the projected annual deficit of $13 billion due to longer life expectancy and delayed workforce entry. Macron confirmed that the reforms would be implemented by autumn 2023, which may result in certain individuals working until 67 to qualify for a full state pension. The initial reforms, which aimed to consolidate 42 special regimes, were deferred due to demonstrations, work stoppages, and the COVID-19 crisis.

In January 2023, Prime Minister Élisabeth Borne announced on FranceInfo radio that the government might flexibly approach the proposed increase of the retirement age to 65 and consider alternative solutions to balance the pension system by 2030. The policy was set to be discussed in the cabinet on January 23, debated in parliament in early February, and its details released on January 10. The government also indicated the possibility of invoking Article 49.3 during the parliamentary debate. This announcement was made ahead of union consultations, and it represented a more adaptable stance from the government regarding the pension reform plan.

In January 2023, the French government, led by Prime Minister Élisabeth Borne, hinted at the possibility of employing Article 49.3 of the Constitution to pass the pension reform, which could raise the retirement age to 65. This article enables the government to enact laws without parliamentary approval, although it opens a window for no-confidence votes against the government. This announcement signaled a more accommodating attitude from the administration regarding the pension reform, with discussions in the cabinet, parliament, and union consultations slated for January and February.

The French government, in January 2023, considered using Article 49.3 of the Constitution to pass the pension reform, raising the retirement age to 65 without parliamentary approval. This option allows for no-confidence votes, but historically, governments have rarely lost these votes due to party divisions. By March 14, The Guardian reported that President Macron had two strategies: negotiating with Les Républicains or employing Article 49.3, which could lead to a challenging no-confidence vote outcome.

The French government officials have expressed that they will not utilize Article 49.3, viewed as undemocratic and potentially exacerbating public unrest. Instead, they have been actively negotiating to secure a majority in the lower house. Union leaders have warned that employing this option would intensify opposition and escalate strikes.

On March 16, French government officials, including President Macron, decided to bypass a vote in the lower house by invoking special powers, avoiding the risk of defeat, after recognizing the potential for increased resistance and strikes if they were to use Article 49.3, which is perceived as undemocratic and inflammatory.

The decision to bypass a vote in the lower house using special powers, known as Article 49.3, was a last-minute choice made by President Macron due to his uncertainty about securing enough lawmakers' support. This move highlights his challenging position in parliament, given that his party has lost its majority in the National Assembly after the 2022 legislative election. The action was taken to prevent the risk of defeat and potential backlash from increased resistance and strikes.

President Macron resorted to using special powers to bypass a vote in the lower house due to his doubt about gaining sufficient support from lawmakers, reflecting his tough situation in parliament after his party lost its majority. This decision aimed to avoid the risk of defeat and criticism from escalating resistance and strikes. In this context, France's trade unions have displayed unity by organizing strikes involving various sectors, including transport, energy, education, and public services. Unions argue that the reform will disproportionately impact lower-income workers in manual jobs who start their careers early, forcing them to work longer than graduates, who are less affected by the changes.

The text indicates that the French public largely opposes President Macron's use of special powers to pass unpopular reforms without a parliamentary vote, as revealed by polls. This sentiment is shared even by some conservative lawmakers who previously supported the reforms, due to their unpopularity. The backlash against the President's move is reflected in the widespread strikes organized by trade unions across various sectors, which argue that the reforms will disproportionately affect lower-income workers.

The use of Article 49.3 to pass reforms without a parliamentary vote is viewed by those on the left as a defeat and a sign of weakness, with the government being perceived as brutal and undemocratic. This perception may harm support for both the government and democratic institutions. The decision has led to a decrease in President Macron's approval ratings, which are now comparable to the low levels during the Yellow Jackets protests.

The Journal du Dimanche reported a significant drop in President Macron's approval ratings, similar to the Yellow Jackets protests period, with 70% of respondents expressing dissatisfaction and only 28% expressing satisfaction. This decline is attributed to the government's use of Article 49.3 to pass reforms without a parliamentary vote, which has been criticized as undemocratic and harmful to support for both the government and democratic institutions. The reforms are also seen as insufficient in addressing the disadvantage women face in the workforce, such as retiring later and receiving lower pensions due to part-time work and maternity leave.

The Journal du Dimanche reports a decline in President Macron's approval ratings, similar to the Yellow Jackets protests period, due to criticism of the government's use of Article 49.3 to pass reforms. Euronews highlights that the reforms would result in women retiring later and working longer than men, with Franck Riester acknowledging that women will be negatively impacted. Additionally, the reforms are said to disproportionately affect the working-class and those in manual jobs.

The text discusses criticism of President Macron's pension reforms, which have led to a decrease in his approval ratings. The reforms would cause women to retire later and have a more significant impact on working-class individuals and those with physically or mentally demanding jobs. While most early retirement exceptions for such workers were previously eliminated, there has been a recent concession allowing a small group to still retire early with a full pension. This change aims to appease opposition, as blue-collar workers typically begin working at a younger age than white-collar workers.

The pension reforms proposed by President Macron have been largely unsuccessful due to strong opposition from unions, who consider the raised retirement age unacceptable. This opposition ultimately led to the withdrawal of a financial law that would have implemented the age increase. The reforms particularly affect working-class individuals and those with demanding jobs, who now must work longer and had initially seen their early retirement exceptions eliminated, with a recent exception for a limited group. The main point of contention is the rise in the retirement age, which unions strongly oppose.

Critics argue that President Macron's pension reforms disproportionately impact lower-wage workers and those with demanding jobs, who now must work longer due to the increased retirement age. Opponents also claim that the government prioritizes businesses and the wealthy, while older adults who want to work face age discrimination in the labor market. The urgency of the reforms is disputed, with critics contending that Macron unfairly burdens blue-collar workers and attacks the valued right to retirement, without raising taxes on the affluent.

Critics, including historian Jean Garrigues, argue that President Macron has overstated the risk of pension system bankruptcy and dismissed alternatives to balance the system, such as raising worker payroll taxes, disconnecting pensions from inflation, or taxing the wealthy more. The official organization overseeing France's pension system has confirmed that there is no imminent danger of insolvency, and long-term deficits are challenging to predict accurately. Opponents also claim that Macron's pension reforms unduly affect lower-wage workers and those with strenuous jobs, who must now work longer due to the raised retirement age, while favoring businesses and the wealthy. The urgency of these reforms is questioned, as critics believe Macron unjustly saddles blue-collar workers and undermines the cherished right to retirement without increasing taxes on the affluent.

Historian Jean Garrigues suggests that President Macron's unpopular pension reforms are partly due to his personal image as a wealthy, out-of-touch leader, which has sparked widespread anger. The accuracy of long-term pension system deficits is questioned, and critics argue that Macron's reforms disproportionately impact lower-wage workers and the elderly while favoring businesses and the wealthy. Opposition to the reforms is amplified because of Macron's association with the project, causing unions and a significant portion of the public to stand against him.

The pension reforms by President Macron have been criticized for being implemented during a cost-of-living crisis, which intensified public anger and protests. The changes were deemed unwise due to the public's sour mood caused by high inflation. Moreover, €7.1 billion of the projected €17.7 billion in savings vanished due to adjustments in the reform. The situation escalated into violence and rioting as demonstrators and police forces confronted each other in the streets.

The protests against President Macron's pension reforms turned violent, with demonstrators and police engaging in riots, and instances of property damage, such as the burning of union property in Chambéry and vandalism of regional health agency offices with anti-vax messages, similar to previous incidents in the area.

Demonstrations against President Macron's pension reforms saw the participation of black bloc groups in several cities, including Paris, Lyon, and Nantes, with significant numbers ranging from 1000 to 3000. These groups were involved in violent protests and property damage. An unauthorized protest in Rennes on 15 April led to looting, with two individuals stealing €25,000 worth of gold from a shop. The authorities identified some of the black bloc members in Lyon as "risky individuals." Instances of vandalism also included anti-vax messages, similar to previous incidents.

On January 19, prior to the use of Article 49.3, approximately 1.12 million people protested nationwide against the government's pension reform plans, with around 80,000 in Paris alone. This was one of the many demonstrations organized by the largest unions across more than 200 locations in France. The protests were in response to the proposed increase in retirement age.

Several major unions joined a nationwide strike to protest the government's pension reform plans, including a proposed increase in retirement age. The French Ministry of the Interior reported that around 80,000 demonstrators gathered in Paris, with some engaging in minor acts of violence. Over 200 protests were held across France, with unions claiming that approximately 2 million people participated, 400,000 of them in Paris. However, President Emmanuel Macron insisted that the pension reforms would still be implemented.

Unions in France announced additional strikes and protests for 31 January to contest the government's pension reform measures, which include raising the retirement age to 64 and increasing annual pension contributions to 43 payments. Transportation disruptions were experienced, with some flights canceled at Orly Airport and Eurostar routes between Paris and London, while Charles de Gaulle Airport had minor delays due to striking air traffic controllers.

On January 21, students and youth organizations held a pre-planned demonstration in Paris, accompanied by similar protests in other cities such as Dinan, Limoges, and Lyon. A week later, on January 31, demonstrations occurred nationwide, with a focus on disrupting public transportation, schools, and electricity production as part of the ongoing opposition to the government's pension reform measures. This resulted in significant transportation issues, including cancellations at Orly Airport and Eurostar routes between Paris and London, as well as minor delays at Charles de Gaulle Airport due to striking air traffic controllers.

Following the pre-planned demonstrations on January 21 in various cities, further protests took place across the country on January 31, targeting public transportation, schools, and electricity production. Additionally, public television broadcasts were affected, with news broadcasts replaced by music. The CGT union reported 2.8 million participants, while the Ministry of Internal Affairs counted 1.272 million protesters. However, the police estimated around 757,000 protesters nationwide. L'intersyndicale had previously organized a third day of protests on February 7, and a fourth day of nationwide protests occurred on February 11.

On February 11, a fourth national protest day took place, with a significant increase in participants compared to the previous protest on February 7. On February 16, protesters participated in new rallies and strikes, with unions reporting 1.3 million participants nationwide, and the interior ministry estimating 440,000. The Intersyndicale announced countrywide strikes starting from March 7, causing ongoing disruptions to train services. On March 7, union members estimated that 1.1 to 1.4 million people joined over 260 protests, while the interior ministry reported a lower number. To intensify the protest's impact, union members obstructed fuel deliveries, aiming to paralyze the French economy. Around 30% of flights from Orly airport in Paris were cancelled on February 16 and March 7-8. The protest continued until March 12.

The Intersyndicale organized the seventh consecutive day of protests on March 11, as the National Assembly and Senate discussed the proposed law, with a final vote anticipated later that month. Despite expectations of 800,000 to 1 million protesters, only around 368,000 participated. The Senate approved an initial vote the next day. Throughout this period, Macron refused to meet with unions, and train services faced continued disruptions. The Senate passed an initial vote on the proposed law, and French unions called for a strong turnout in a final day of strikes and protests before the National Assembly vote, set to occur after the eighth national mobilization.

The Senate approved a preliminary vote on the proposed legislation, and French unions urged a large participation in the last day of strikes and demonstrations before the National Assembly vote, which is scheduled following the eighth national mobilization. In relation to the disruptions, Transport Minister Clément Beaune stated that there would be some disturbances to public transportation and flights, but it would not reach the same level of disruptions as in previous protests. The French police anticipated 650,000 to 850,000 protesters countrywide, a number lower than the largest protests from the previous week. Union balloons and loud music marked the afternoon gathering at the Esplanade des Invalides. Strikes involved train drivers, teachers, dock workers, oil refinery workers, and garbage collectors, with a lower strike turnout in the energy and transport sectors compared to previous days. Le Monde questioned the accuracy of the protest attendance figures reported by the Interior Ministry and the CGT.

The French police, having predicted a lower number of protesters compared to the previous week, arranged for the removal of accumulated garbage along the protest route due to instances of it being used to start fires or throw trash at officers. A strong security presence accompanied the protestors, who marched through the Left Bank on clear streets. Regrettably, a subset of the protestors were reported to have targeted a small business, leading to the detainment of nine individuals within the first three hours of the march.
